Note: [letter from Northwestern Mutual Life] Dear Mr. Thomas, Your activity must require your attendance at so many of these affairs that perhaps you connot even keep track of them. During the course of the American Academy of Achievement Meeting, time was so short that I had no opportunity for personal visit with you but I did think that these snaps that I got were good enough so that you might like to have them for your collection. Please accept them with my compliments. Sincerely, [signed] John O. Todd
Subject files: Amos 'N' Andy
Amos 'N' Andy
Verso: Amos + Andy

Note: AMOS 'N' ANDY - 20 YEARS AGO: But in 1928 when Freeman (Amos) Gosden and Charles (Andy) Correll first went on the air as a team, on Chicago's WMAQ, they were known as Sam 'N' Henry. A year later, they changed their names to Amos 'N' Andy, became a network show and an immediate national hit. Theirs was the first nightly continual broadcast - 12/28/48

Subject files: Antarctica

USN 808874, 12-31-1956 Part of Adelie penguin rookery at Cape Hallett, which has estimated population of 150,000; Official US Navy photograph by Dietrich, Joi; Released; U.S. Naval Photographic Center; U.S Naval Station, Anacostia; Washington 25, D.C.

Subject - Two scientists from the United Kingdom's Halley Bay Station on the Eastern coast of Antarctica explore the ice cliffs along the coast. Extreme winds, often reaching 100 MPH, and blowing snow carves natural sculptures into the thick ice mountains. Antarctica is the highest of thw World's seven continents with an average elevation of about 7,500 feet. It's also the coldest and windiest of the continents. The Soviet Union's Vostok Station recorded the world's coldest temperature of 126.9 degrees below zero Fahrenheit on August 24, 1960

Task Force Forty Three, XAM 0449(L)-10-61; 25 October 1961; Emperor penguin and chick at Cape Crozier, Antarctica. The Emperor penguin is one of the largest birds, weighing close to ninety pounds and standing three feet tall. The Emperor lays and hatches its single egg on the ice during the long Antarctic winter night. Eggs are incubated in a snug corner between the tops of the penguin's feet and the rolls of fat on their lower abdomen?. Credit line should read, "Official U.S. Navy Photograph," by Photographer's Mate Chief (PHC F. Kazukaitis, USN)

Task Force Forty Three, XAM 2301(L)-1-62; 10 January 1962; Concerned mother penguin sits on her chick and an incubating egg at the same time in the midst of a crowded rookery at Inexpressible Island, 200 miles north of McMurdo Station, Antarctica. These penguins, of the Adelie variety, hatch and raise their young during the relatively mild Antarctic summer. Credit line to read, "Official U.S. Navy Photograph ," by Photographer's Mate Airman (PHAN) Mark W. Huntley, USN

[6 copies] 20 Nov 1962; General James E. Doolittle (left) and explorer-news commentator Lowell Thomas (right) greet two of the Antarctic support activities men who wintered over at South Pole Station during DEEPFREEZE 62. Next to General Doolittle is Claud Craig, RMCA, USN; to his left is Harold D. Crain, UT1, USN. Both Craig and Crain were guests of Commander, Antarctic Support Activities at a midnight buffet supper for the DEEPFREEZE 62 Pole winter over men at the McMurdo Station mess hall at which General Doolittle and Mr. Thomas were present.

22 November 1962, Congressman Poage of Texas, and Lowell Thomas, renown radio news commentator, partake of traditional Thanksgiving dinner at the enlisted men's chow hall at Advance Headquarters for Operations Deep Freeze at Harewood Christchurch, New Zealand. They arrived at Harewood International Airport Thursday morning after completing an inspection tour of U. S. scientific bases in the Antarctic.

31 December 1962; An Adelie penguin with her baby chick at Cape Crozier, Antarctica. Adelies are the clowns of the Antarctic and often offer some unusual entertainment to the men of "Deep Freeze." Note: [letter from Westinghouse Electric Corporation] Dear Lowell: Here is the picture of you and Harold Arlin at the Westinghouse "Home of Tomarrow" here in Mansfield. The delay in getting it to you was the result of borrowing Harold's copy and having it copied in our photographic department. A couple of notes -- the "Home of Tomorrow" was dedicated on February 21, 1934 -- your broadcast was on March 15, 1934. Hope you find the picture pleasurable. Sincerely, [signed] J. Gilbert Baird

Subject files: Around the world special passenger flight (Pan American World Airways)

Note: LT launching the first passenger flight around the world. Directly behind him are Juan Trippe, publishers Frank Gannett, Gardner Cowles and Roy Howard. On the left is Edwin D. Canham, publisher of the Christian Science Monitor; behind him is Maurice T. Moore, chairman of the board of Time, Inc; and at top Barry Faris of INS. (Electra [Electra Nicks?] on steps) and to her right James Stahlman, publisher of the Nashville Banner

Note: Call PAN AMERICAN - Photographic Dept. Many years ago, in the thirties, Mr. Thomas helped you folks at Pan Am to launch the first passenger fligt around the world, from LaGuardia. It might have been in the forties. Juan Trippe, Roy Howard, Stallman, were there. L.T. did a b.c from the steps of the plane and Mr. Trippe was in the picture at Mr, T's side. L.T. wants one or two or three or 4, in which Trippe is in the center and can be seen slearly. Let him have a few to make a choice.

June 15, 1965; Lowell Thomas, veteran broadcaster, author and explorer, today joined ceremonies marking the NYSE listings of Capital Cities Broadcasting Corporation, of which he is a founder and director. From the left are: Keith Funston, Exchange President; Lowell Thomas; Frank M. Smith, company chairman and Harold Mackey of McMannus & Mackey, specialists in the stock. Mr. Thomas bought the first 100 shares (ticker symbol CCB) at 37 ½ to open trading. The company, headquartered in New York, operates radio and TV stations in six states

Note: From: New York Stock Exchange, 11 Wall Street, New York, New York 10005, Contact: Ralph H. From the left are: Keith Funston, Exchange President; Lowell Thomas; Frank M. Smith, company chairman and Harold Mackey of McMannus & Mackey, specialists in the stock. Note: "High Adventure" vagabonds sail to Arabia on last stop of season's television trail; Aboard the good ship "Odyssey" (Odyssey Productions), Lowell Thomas and his son, Lowell, Jr. sail into the Persian Gulf for the last seasonal installment of "High Adventure With Lowell Thomas" Friday, March 27 (CBS Television Network), 8:00-9:00 PM, EST). Earlier this television season, before navigating their rugged way into the upcoming "Arabian Nights" adventure, the international vagabonds visited Alaska, the Belgian Congo and the Pacific's Danger Island; Subject: Lowell Thomas, Sr. and Jr.; Program: "High Adventure with Lowell Thomas" ; On Air: Friday, March 27, 8:00-9:00 PM, EST; Sponsor: General Motors Corp; "Full" 2/27/1959

NEW YORK BUREAU; PUTTING AN ODYSSEY ON FILM, CAIRO: - Globe-trotter Lowell Thomas, producing a film called "Seven Wonders of the World," stands before two ancient marvels in Egypt - the Great Pyramid of Cheops (background) and the Sphinx. The noted commentator and adventurer recently completed a globe-circling trip to 32 countries working on the film, the third "Cinerama" production. The modern odyssey covered 100,000 miles and the Cinerama crew worked with two airplanes and five directors; CREDTI (UNITED PRESS PHOTO) 11/18/55

Note: NEW YORK BUREAU; PUTTING AN ODYSSEY ON FILM, CAIRO: - Globe-trotter Lowell Thomas, producing a film called "Seven Wonders of the World," stands before two ancient marvels in Egypt - the Great Pyramid of Cheops (background) and the Sphinx. The noted commentator and adventurer recently completed a globe-circling trip to 32 countries working on the film, the third "Cinerama" production. Subject files: Cinerama (Seven Wonders of the World)

Lowell Thomas, producer of the third Cinerama adventure, "Seven Wonders of the World," examines a model of the Sphinx with pretty Eileen Salama. Miss Salama handled all the advance arrangements for the Cinerama expedition during its visit to one of the most remote corners of the world, Wadi Beihan in southern Arabia. There Cinerama camera men filmed a stampede of thousands of camels and were guests of honor at a banquet held by the fabulous Sherif Hussein

Note: Lowell Thomas, producer of the third Cinerama adventure, "Seven Wonders of the World," examines a model of the Sphinx with pretty Eileen Salama. Miss Salama handled all the advance arrangements for the Cinerama expedition during its visit to one of the most remote corners of the world, Wadi Beihan in southern Arabia. There Cinerama camera men filmed a stampede of thousands of camels and were guests of honor at a banquet held by the fabulous Sherif Hussein

The beautiful Taj Mahal, one of the wonders of the modern world, with Lalitha Bhatt. The model, valued at over $3,000 and owned by J. J. Singh of the India Shop in New York City, is made entirely of marble like the original

Note: Lowell Thomas, producer of the newest Cinerama picture, "Seven Wonders of the World," examines a model of the beautiful Taj Mahal, one of the wonders of the modern world, with Lalitha Bhatt. The model, valued at over $3,000 and owned by J. J. Singh of the India Shop in New York City, is made entirely of marble like the original

East and West meet over a Japanese pagoda as Morigai Mitsuko instructs Lowell Thomas in the finer points of Oriental architecture. The noted commentator, producer of the new Cinerama adventure, "Seven Wonders of the World," spent several months of intensive research before starting to shoot sequences in Japan

Fascinating Lake Baikal, in Central Siberia. It is the deepest in the world (almost a mile deep) and 353 miles long. 1800 species of plant and animal life have been identified; ¾ of them are found no place else on earth. It is a highlight of both the 8-day and 15-day Alaska Airlines tour. Intourist photograph

Photograph from Intourist; Samarkand in Russia's Central Asia is a delightful mixture of the surrounding countries, truly the land of the Arabian Nights. Crossroads of historic camel caravans and ravaging warlords. The ruins of Tamerlane's early 15th century Tomb, and other turquoise-colored tile domes ar a photographer's delight

Moscow River and The Kremlin, which is an historic, walled fortress in the center of Moscow. Many of its most famous buildings are now museums. A complete tour is included in Alaska Airlines 15-day, all-inclusive tours out of Anchorage. Moscow River in foreground; Intourist photo

Subject files: Cinerama (Aut Swenson Thrillcade)
Caption: Headed your way, the Aut Swenson Thrillcade, jumbo of all thrill shows

Caption: A '56 Ford Sunliner in a ramp-to-ramp leap over dancing Dyna ', 2 ton pachyderm, at the Provincial Exhibition of Manitoba and Western Canada Trade Fair, Brandon, Manitoba July 5th. An alert photographer of the Winnipeg Free Press snapped this prize-winning photo which appeared on the front page of the Winnipeg Free Press, July 6th edition; This same stunt will be repeated at the State Fair of Oklahoma at Oklahoma City, September 24-29 when the Aut Swenson Thrillcade combined with star-studded hippodrome features will be presented before afternoon grandstand throngs

Sunset over "Spook Mountain" overlooking the mining camp at Slab Fork, W. Va.; Note: Two little colored boys talking one day at Slab Fork, W. Va. One pointed across the "holler." "See that there moun-tin" he asked his companion. "Dat's Spook Moun-tain" , "Why you call dat Spook Moun-tin?", "Cause'n I know a man went up thar one day, ad' he sayed, "Spook, cum git my wife." An when dat man went home his wide was jus' as daid as a dwag." After a moment's silence the little fellow continued, I bet iff'n you went over there an' say "Spook, cum git me," we never would see hide or hair of you again.......I bet there ain't a man in the whole Slab Fork 'ud dare go up that moun-tin and holler "Here Spook!"
Verso: V2-10 Sunset over "Spook Mountain" overlooking the mining camp at Slab Fork, W. Va.; Photograph by R.W. Barton, Pelham Manor, N.Y.

After a moment's silence the little fellow continued, I bet iff'n you went over there an' say "Spook, cum git me," we never would see hide or hair of you again.......I bet there ain't a man in the whole Slab Fork 'ud dare go up that moun-tin and holler "Here Spook!"

V10-2 Homstead [sic] of "Bad" John Wright, near Jenkins, Kentucky, said to be prototype of "Jud Tolliver" of Fox's book, "The Trail of the Lonesome Pine."
